title: Anatole Shub
text:
Anatole Shub (May 19, 1928 in <a href="The%20Bronx">The Bronx</a>, <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> – July 2, 2006 in <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>) was an American <a href="author">author</a>, <a href="journalist">journalist</a>, <a href="research">research</a>er, <a href="editing">editor</a>, <a href="news">news</a> director and Russian <a href="public%20opinion">public opinion</a> analyst.
Shub attended <a href="Townsend%20Harris%20High%20School">Townsend Harris High School</a> and then joined the <a href="US%20Navy">US Navy</a> in 1945. He graduated from the <a href="City%20College%20of%20New%20York">City College of New York</a> and attended the <a href="Medill%20School%20of%20Journalism">Medill School of Journalism</a> at <a href="Northwestern%20University">Northwestern University</a> and the <a href="Columbia%20University%20Graduate%20School%20of%20Journalism">Graduate School of Journalism</a> at <a href="Columbia%20University">Columbia University</a>.
His first jobs in journalism included writing and then editing at "<a href="The%20New%20Leader">The New Leader</a>", a <a href="left-wing%20politics">leftist</a> but <a href="anti-communism">anti-communist</a> magazine whose editor was his brother-in-law, <a href="Melvin%20J.%20Lasky">Melvin J. Lasky</a>, and associate editor at "<a href="Commentary%20%28magazine%29">Commentary</a>". Next, he was an editor at "<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>", where he won a fellowship from the Institute of Current World Affairs, which allowed him to travel in the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> and <a href="Eastern%20Europe">Eastern Europe</a>.
In 1964, he was hired by "<a href="The%20Washington%20Post">The Washington Post</a>" to open a bureau in <a href="Bonn">Bonn</a> and report on <a href="Germany">Germany</a> and Eastern Europe. Next, he was moved to the <a href="Moscow">Moscow</a> bureau, where his reporting on <a href="dissident">dissident</a>s and the political role of the army got him expelled in 1969.
More recently, Shub was news director at <a href="Radio%20Free%20Europe">Radio Free Europe</a> and analyst for the <a href="United%20States%20Information%20Agency">United States Information Agency</a>, studying Russian public opinion.
Shub was married to Joyce Lasky (sister of <a href="Floria%20Lasky">Floria Lasky</a>) with whom he had a son and daughter; they later divorced. He then married the author Barbara (née Bellman) Raskin, the former wife of progressive social critic <a href="Marcus%20Raskin">Marcus Raskin</a>; the marriage also ended in divorce.
Shub died of a <a href="stroke">stroke</a> and <a href="pneumonia">pneumonia</a>.
